title-group.article-title: Strength of aluminum single-lap bonded joints in various disbond size at circular and semi-circular notches

article-meta.aff: Laboratoire de Modélisation Numérique et Expérimentale des Phénomènes Mécaniques, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University Abdelhamid Ibn Badis of Mostaganem, Algeria

author-notes.corresp: Djamel Ouinas, Laboratoire de Modélisation Numérique et Expérimentale des Phénomènes Mécaniques, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University Abdelhamid Ibn Badis of Mostaganem, Algeria. Email: douinas@netcourrier.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Applications of assembly bonded technique have been extended currently to various industrial fields. Adhesively bonded joints are widely used in the aeronautics and astronautics industry as a result of their high strength and convenience in using the single-lap joint. The geometry of bonded single-lap joint is nonlinear and causes the eccentricity due to the non-collinear applied load, which conducts to a significant stress concentration at the extremities of overlap area, where the cracks may initiate. In this article, the finite element (FE) method is used to analyze the behavior of a bonded lap joint of aluminum adherend. The comparison of stress concentration factor and stress intensity factor of crack emanating from the circular and semi-circular notches are investigated. The single-lap bonded joints were analyzed to study the combined effect of the notch and the disbond as they pertain to joint strength and failure conditions. The results show that the stress concentration factor and stress intensity factor are affected by the negative disbond effect and their values are strongly proportional to its size.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Adhesively bonded joints are widely used in aerospace and marine structures as a result of their high strength to weight ratio and convenience in using the single-lap joint is the most common one, although it is geometrically nonlinear due to the non-collinear load path [1,2]. The bonded joints are a means for transferring load in the construction, they are potential failure sites due to the presence of geometric and material discontinuities that cause high stress concentrations leading to the failure of the joint [1,2]. However, shear and peel stress concentrations develop near the edges of the overlap and failure usually initiates at the ends of the joint and propagates as a delamination between the adherends [3]. Several studies have shown that stitching the overlap of single-lap composite joints may significantly increase static strength [4,5] and fatigue life [6,7], but have also indicated that the global performance of stitched lap-joints depends on a number of parameters, such as the stitch material, the density and pattern of stitches, the lamination sequence of the adherends, etc.

The effect of the bonding methods, overlap lengths and material types have been examined [8–10]. It is well known that the mechanical properties of composites and adhesives change depending on the temperature, moisture and environments [11,12]. Cho et al. [13] calculated the stress distributions in tubular lap joints using FE analysis [14]. Oterkus et al. [14] investigated the effect of tapered edges on the performance of the joint. Belingardi et al. [15] discussed the results from the FE analysis as the smaller the inner chamfering angle in the unloaded ends of the adherend, the lower the peak stress in single-lap joint.

The determination of the strain and stress fields in bonded lap joint presents difficulties resulting from the geometry and properties of the dissimilar materials. The eccentric loading can lead to the bending in the single-lap joint and the variations of local stress near the ends of the overlap area are characterized by very high gradients. The gradients of the stress components depend on the elastic properties of the adherend, the adhesive and the common geometry [1]. Ouinas et al. [16] examined the disbond effect at the crack tip emanating from a circular notch located in the overlap region. They indicate that the maximum shear stresses are located at a distance of about 18% that of the lap length whateverthe type of material used.

This study presents the comparison analysis by the FE method of the fracture behavior of adhesive bonded lap joints using two notched specimen: circular and semi-circular notches. The analysis of substrates of various materials constituting the assembly with a single-lap joint shows that the parameters influencing the performance of the assembly are the properties of the plates and the adhesive. The effects of the adhesive shear modulus, the adhesive thickness and the overlap length on the variations of the stress concentration are examined. The disbond effect at the crack tip emanating from a circular and semi-circular notch located in the overlap region is highlighted.

sec.title: Geometrical model
sec.p:
In this modeling, a bonded lap joint with two thin aluminum 2024 T3 adherend rectangular plates of various materials having the following dimensions: length h of 127 mm, width w of 152.4 mm and a thickness es of 1 mm is considered. A comparison is carried out between two different geometrical configurations: the adherent plates comprise a centered circular notch for the first case and of the nonsymmetrical semi-circular notch for the second. The radius of notches is identical ρnot=12.7mm. The assembly is subjected to normal traction load giving a remote stress state of σ=120MPa. The plates are bonded over an overlap length c by an adhesive of shear modulus Ga=965MPa and thickness ea=0.127mm. For symmetry reasons, only a half of the structure is used for computing (Figure 1). The properties of the materials used in this study are listed in Table 1. Plane stress conditions are assumed. After the bonding of the overlap area of the substrates, the symmetry is obtained for two assembled structures (with circular and semi-circular notches) with respect to the x-axis. To make a comparison between the two notched structures, we maintain the same boundary conditions. Table 1.
Mechanical properties of the adherend and adhesive
Property Aluminum Adhesive
E(GPa) 72
ν 0.33 0.32
G(GPa)
0.965
Figure 1.
Geometrical model of the simple lap joint with presence: (a) circular notch and (b) semi-circular notch.

sec.title: Numerical studies
sec.p:
The behavior of the joint in the presence of disbond between the adherends was analyzed by a two-dimensional geometrically linear FE analysis conducted with the FRANC2D/L (Fracture Analysis Code for 2D Layered structure).This code was originally developed at Cornell University and modified for multi-layers at Kansas State University, and is based on the theory of linear and non-linear elastic fracture mechanics [17]. In this study, the following assumptions were assumed in order to obtain the essential structural response features:
– Each layer was considered as an individual two-dimensional structure under a state of plane stress.
– The adhesive layer is homogeneous, linear, elastic and isotropic.
– The adhesive was supposed to deform only in shear and the deformation is uniform throughout the adhesive thickness.
– The surface shear transmitted through the adhesive is assumed to act as a surface traction on the adherents.
– The shear stresses in the adhesive are given by
(1)τ=Gaea(u1-u2) where u1 and u2 are the displacements in adherend1 and adherend2, respectively.

The whole structure was meshed using the standard eight-noded serendipity elements with quadratic shape functions. These elements perform well for elastic analysis and have the advantage that the stress singularity at the crack tip can be incorporated in the solution by moving the eight nodes to the quarter-point locations [18]. Figure 1 shows a typical mesh model of the total structure with notches. Since, the FE analysis was aimed at computing stress intensity factor (SIF), the mesh of the FE model was particularly refined near the crack tip to assure the convergence of SIF components to stable values.The modified crack closure techniques were used to calculate the SIF. The crack tip was modeled with a ring of collapsed quadrilateral elements.

sec.title: Notch effect on the variation of the shear stress τYZ
sec.p:
To illustrate this effect we tested several sizes of the circular notch characterized by radius ρnot. Figures 2 and 3 represents the variation of shear stresses τYZ along a vertical line crossing the adhesive layer. It is noticed that the effect of the notch size on the stress in the adhesive is significant. The increase in size influences the variation of the maximum stress at the level of the substrate edges, which can reach the center of the lap distance, depending on the notch radius. This behavior is explained by the fact that for large radii, the notch is very close to the free edge of the adhesive layer. This interaction increases the displacements in the substrate and hence the maximum stress in the adhesive layer. It can be said that there is an effect of interaction between the presence of the notch and the free edge of the adhesive layer. This interaction effect is more sensitive when the notch radius tends to approach the free edge of the adhesive layer. A similar behavior is noticed in the case of the side semi-circular notch, except that maximum shear stresses are increased by 18% [3]. Figure 3.
Circular notch effect on the variation of adhesive shear stresses. Figure 2.
Semi-circular notch effect on the variation of adhesive shear stresses.

sec.title: Stress concentration factor
sec.p:
When the material contains a geometrical macroscopic defect, the tensile strength decreases considerably. The defects constitute privileged zones where the local stress value can reach the tensile strength. In other words, these stresses generally have a value more raised than the applied load. Although the applied stress is very low compared to the tensile yield stress of material, it can, however, reach locally much higher values than the latter, because the stress concentration due to the presence of geometrical defect. Figure 4 shows the comparison of the stress concentration factor (SCF) as a function of the circular and semi-circular notches radius. The plates are bonded by an adhesive shear modulus Ga=965MPa and thickness ea=0.127mm. Figure 4.
Variation of the SCF vs notches radius.
SCF: stress concentration factor.

The SCF increases proportionally with the increase the notch radius. The obtained values for the semi-circular radius are more important than those obtained by the circular notches. The maximum SCF obtained for the largest notch radius which is about 2.3.

When a material is subjected to an external load lower clearly to that of the tensile strength, this stress can, in certain zones, to reach a value equal to the tensile strength. The zones where the local stress can reach and exceed a critical values, being able to lead to the starting and the propagation of the crack, and consequently to the damage of material. The maximum stress is located at the notch root, which allows the characterizing of the notch by an SCF defined by the relationship between the maximum stress and the applied stress; this factor depends generally only on the notch geometry. For a circular or semi-circular notch, the SCF depends only on the radius. One notices a symmetry of the factors Kt whether the loading: tensile or pressure. Ouinas et al. [19,20] indicate, when the circular notch radius varies between 2.54 and 12.7 mm the variation of the SCF, which is not very significant, lies between 2.86 and 3.016. On the other hand, the influence of the semi-circular notch radius is more significant owing to the fact that the SCF varies between 3.068 and 3.30, when the notch radius varies between 2.54 and 12.7 mm [19,20].

sec.title: Effect of the crack emanating from notch on the variation of the maximum shear stress
sec.p:
The results of Figure 5 indicate that the influence of the crack length emanating from notches of radius ρnot=12.7mm on the variation of the maximum shear stress τYZ. The maximum stress is located at the notch root, which allows the characterizing of the notch by a SCF defined by the relationship between the maximum stress and the applied stress; this factor depends generally onlyon the notch geometry. Figure 5.
Influence of the crack length emanating from the notches on the variation of the maximum shear stress.

Figure 6 shows that the increase in the shear stress is more marked when the length of the crack emanating from the notch is lower than 10 mm. Beyond this value the variation is not very sensitive, i.e. the stress remains quasi-constant. It is also noted that the radius of the stress field produced by the notches is in the order of the size of their radii. Figure 6.
Variation of the maximum shear stress in the adhesive layer vs notch radius.

The zones where the local stress can reach and exceed critical values lead to the start and the growth of the crack, and consequently to the damage of material. Several researchers [21–24] have investigated the effect of notch on the behavior of materials. It is important to point out that the SCF factor for the semi-circular notches is higher than that of the central holes. The semi-circular notches are more dangerous and exhibit more risks of starting cracks. It is noticed that for the same geometry of the plates and the same values of the notch radius, the SCFs for the centered notches are lower than those of the semi-circular notches, which means that the second notched structures will be precracked more easily than the first.

The maximum shear stresses produced by the semi-circular notch are more important than those produced on the level of the centered notches. Moreover, they are increasingly important with the increase of the geometrical radius defects (Figure 6). One notices also a symmetrical behavior in the case of compression, except that the values of the stress are negative.

sec.title: Stress intensity factor
sec.p:
The SIF characterizes the stress and displacements fields at the crack tip; he is known by its direct influence on the propagation velocity of the crack whether it is in monotonous or cyclic loading. To study the behavior of the cracks emanating from circular en semi-circular notches with and without the presence of lap joints, we plotted the variation of the normalized SIF as a function of crack length (Figure 7). In the case of single-lap joint it is assumed that the crack exists only in the substrate. The mesh around the notch and crack is well refined. Figure 7.
Variation of the SIF vs crack length emanating from notches.
SIF: stress intensity factor.

It can be noticed that, in the absence of lap joint, the SIF increases appreciably with the increase of the crack size. For small cracks lengths, the SIFs resulting from the circular and semi-circular notches are appreciably identical, whether it is with or without presence of the lap joint, what shows that the behavior of the short cracks does not depend much on the notch type.

On the other hand, when the crack length increases, the SIF for the crack emanating from semi-circular notch without the influence of the lap joint is much more important compared to the central circular notch; their difference in SIF values takes more and more importance while moving away from the notch root. Ouinas et al. [25,26] compared the results of the computing of the SIF obtained for cracks emanating from the circular notch and the semi-circular notch with those obtained by simulation of Kujawski model [23] established for the short cracks emanating from the notch root. The comparison of these results showed a good coincidence for the short cracks. In the case of the central notch the difference variation did not exceed 6% [26] while for the semi-circular notch the maximum variation is 10%.

A crack emanating from a semi-circular notch is propagated more quickly than a crack emanating from a circular notch. In the case of the presence of the lap joint, the SIF decreases gradually while moving away from the notches root while the produced driving force of the two geometrical defects loses the influence.

sec.title: Influence of the disbond
sec.p: The asymptotic value of SIF for patched crack is approximated by the following formula [27] (2)K∞=σ0πΛ where πΛ is defined as the characteristic crack length without disbond.

The stress obtained explicitly from the one-dimensional theory of bonded joints was used [28]. The reduced stress is expressed as σ0=σ∞/(1+S), where S=Er'er/EP'eP represents the stiffness ratio between the plate and the reinforcement. Here E'=E/(1-ν2) is Young's modulus for plane strain condition, E'=E for plane stress condition.The stress obtained explicitly from the one-dimensional theory of bonded joints was used [28]. The disbond is assumed uniform along the crack and its width noted wd is equal to the crack length; i.e. a=wd. Now considering the model proposed by Albat [29] (3)πΛd=πΛ+d(1+1S) where πΛd is the effective limit crack length or the characteristic crack length with disbond, and d is the disbond size (Figure 8). Figure 8.
Geometrical model of the patch with disbond d.
After the mathematical transformations we obtain a linear form of (K∞d)2 (4)(K∞d)2=K∞2+Cd,
Such as the constant C=σ02(1+1S). Where K∞d is the SIF at the limit of the patch with a disbond d and K∞ the SIF at the limit of the patch without a disbond.

sec.title: Effect of disbond on the stress intensity factor
sec.p: It is known that when a tensile load is applied on structure, the delamination always started from one end of the joint; in this case, in presence of notch, the disbond grow in notch across the ligament of the specimen. The disbond front of FE models was therefore assumed to start from notch. The disbond is characterized by a distance d along the crack.

Figures 9 and 10 show a comparison of the evolution of the SIF emanating from the circular and semi-circular notches as a function of crack length with and without the presence of disbond, respectively. The circular and semi-circular notches radii is ρnot=12.7mm. Three distances d of disbond, d=ρnot,0.5ρnot and d=0 are considered. It is noticed that the behavior of the crack is similar for the two types of notches, except that the SIF of the crack emanating from the semi-circular notch is more important than that of the circular notch. We note, however, the increase in the distance of disbond d amplifies the SIF. It is interesting to point out that the SIF is not a continuously increasing function of disbond length; in fact, the stress depends on many parameters, such as the stiffness of the adherend material, the overall bending of the joint, the overlap size and others. Figure 9.
Effect of disbond on the variation of the SIF vs crack length emanating from circular notch.
SIF: stress intensity factor. Figure 10.
Disbond effect on SIF vs crack length emanating from semi-circular notch.
SIF: stress intensity factor.

In the presence of the disbond effect, the maximum SIF corresponds to the crack length a=5.1mm, i.e. two-fifths of the notch radius a=2ρnot/5. Beyond this value the SIF decreases with the crack length. This reduction is due to propagation of the crack of the non-bonded zone towards the bonded part. Thus, the crack grow will be more or less decelerated. If d=0 (without disbond) it is noticed that the curve of the SIF decreases gradually with the importance of the crack size.

Figure 9 indicates that the relative variation of the SIF between a null disbond d = 0 and a disbond d=0.5ρnot varies from 14% to 32% and varies from 33% to 42% for semi-circular notch (Figure 10). This variation will be raised 16% when the length of the crack a=2ρnot/5. When the disbond is equal to the notch radius (d=ρnot), the variations of the SIF will be raised of 18%. The influence of disbond on the SIF of a crack emanating from semi-circular notch of radius ρnot=12.7mm repaired by a composite patch was highlighted by Ouinas et al. [20] These authors showed that the increase of distance d affects the variation of the SIF and increases indefinitely with the increase of the disbond.

sec.title: Effect of the distance of disbond
sec.p:
Figure 11 shows the influence of the disbond on the SIF of a stationary crack emanating from circular notch of radius ρnot=12.7mm. The crack length is the same order of the notch radius a=2ρnot/5. The figure indicates that the SIF increases proportionally with the increase of the disbond d. Indeed, the SIF increases indefinitely with the increase of the disbond. It is marked that the difference between the SIF of the crack emanating from two types of notches, grows with the increase in the disbond size. The semi-circular notch effect is more important than that of the circular notch. The SIF KI does not have an asymptotic value. We notice that the mode I crack growth is greatly affected by the extent of disbond. Figure 11.
Variation of the SIF vs disbond.
SIF: stress intensity factor.

Figure 12 shows the variation of the square of the SIF as a function of the disbond. The disbond varies linearly with KI2. The maximum values of the SIF are obtained for the larger disbond area. On the other hand; the variation of the factor KI with disbond is a second-order polynomial. Figure 12.
Variation of the square of the SIF vs disbond.
SIF: stress intensity factor.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The following conclusions can be drawn from this study:
The maximum shear stresses produced by the semi-circular notch are more important than those produced by the centered notches. Moreover, they are increasingly important with the increase of the geometrical radius defects.
The radius notch effect on the stress in the adhesive layer at the adherend edge has a very significant impact.
When the crack length increases, the SIF for the crack emanating from semi-circular notch without the lap joint is larger compared to the central circular notch. The difference in SIF values becomes more significant while moving away from the notch root. In the presence of lap joint, the difference between the SIF values is small.
The emanating crack from a semi-circular notch is propagated more quickly than a crack emanating from a circular notch. In the case of the presence of the lap joint, the SIF decreases gradually while moving away from the notches root while the produced driving force of the two geometrical defects loses the influence.
The negative effect of disbond amplified the SIF and play a major role in the fracture behavior of lap bonded joint. The increase in disbond area is proportional to the increase of the SIF. This latter, does not have an asymptotic value and the mode I crack growth is greatly affected by the extent of disbond.
The increase with growing crack length with presence of disbond always exhibits higher KI values, with regard to a bonded lap. The variation of KI2 versus the disbond has a linear relationship.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
